Acute pancreatitis: Abdominal pain that radiates to your back
Abdominal pain that feels worse after eating

swelling in the ankles and tummy

swollen lips, tongue, eyes or face

feeling that your bowel doesn't empty completely

irritable, and being out of control during outbursts

dry, crackling sound in the lungs while breathing in
Wider and rounder than normal fingertips and toes (clubbing)

worsening symptoms with attempts at controlled movement
worsening symptoms with attempts at improved posture

Gradual difficulty walking and speaking, memory loss, tingling

Bacterial meningitis: lack of interest in feeding in infants
Bone cancer: Pain in the bones and joints

The person shows no reaction to pain
The eyes don't blink when the eye surface is touched (corneal reflex)

The eyes don't move when ice water is poured into the ear (oculo-vestibular reflex)

inability to speak or understand language

Nipple discharge other than breast milk, including blood

Changes to your nipple, such as redness or scaling, a nipple that begins to turn inward

thick skin at base of big toe

feeling that your throat is blocked
blocked or stuffy nose that you cannot clear
feeling of mucus running down the back of your throat
reduced sense of smell and taste

dysuria, a condition caused by urethral inflammation

Pain in the belly that gets worse when you eat
Severe belly (abdominal) pain that may be constant

Impaired judgment and trouble controlling mood and emotions
Cirrhosis: web of swollen blood vessels in the skin or yellow skin and eyes

Rectal bleeding — passing small amount of blood with stool

No responses of limbs, except for reflex movements
No response to painful stimuli, except for reflex movements
Cough: feeling of liquid running down the back of your throat (postnasal drip)

Heartburn or a sour taste in your mouth

feeling like you need to pee again soon after going to the toilet
urine that's dark, cloudy or strong-smelling
pain low down in your tummy
feeling generally unwell, achy, sick and tired

asking others to speak loudly, slowly and more clearly

rashes on skin or red spots

Fever of 100 F (38 C) or higher

partial or total loss of vision
in your eye that's increasing in size
